clinical_study.brief_title: Midline vs. Paramedian Approaches for US-assisted Spinal Anesthesia
clinical_study.official_title: Midline Versus Paramedian Approaches for Ultrasound-assisted Spinal Anesthesia: a Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Ultrasound has emerged as an useful tool for neuraxial blockade. The aim of this study is to compare the efficacy and safety between the midline approach and paramedian approach for ultrasound-assisted spinal anesthesia in adult patients.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative (from the first insertion of needle to patient's skin, until the completion of spinal anesthetic injection)
primary_outcome.description: the number of forward advancements of the spinal needle in a given interspinous space, i.e., withdrawal and redirection of spinal needle without exiting the skin

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of spinal needle insertion attempts
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative (from the first insertion of needle to patient's skin, until the completion of spinal anesthetic injection)
secondary_outcome.description: the number of times the spinal needle was withdrawn from the skin and reinserted

secondary_outcome.time_frame: intraoperative (time taken for establish the landmark, from start of US scanning to completion of scanning
secondary_outcome.description: time from placement of the ultrasound probe on the skin to the completion of markings.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time taken for performing spinal anesthetic
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative (from insertion of the needle to the completion of injection)
secondary_outcome.description: time from needle insertion to the completion of injection

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 20 minutes after the completion of spinal anesthetic injection
secondary_outcome.description: thoracic dermatome level of sensory block assessed by loss of cold sensation tested with 2% chlorhexidine swab

secondary_outcome.measure: Incidence of radicular pain, paraesthesia, and blood tapping in the spinal needle
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Intraoperative (from the first insertion of needle, until the completion of spinal anesthetic injection)
secondary_outcome.description: Incidence of radicular pain, paraesthesia, and blood tapping in the spinal needle during the spinal anesthesia procedure

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be asked immediately after the completion of spinal anesthesia
secondary_outcome.description: 11-point verbal rating scale (0=no pain, 10=most pain imaginable)

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be asked immediately after the completion of spinal anesthesia
secondary_outcome.description: 11-point verbal rating scale (0=no discomfort, 10=most discomfort imaginable)

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient satisfaction score of spinal anesthesia procedure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be asked immediately after the completion of spinal anesthesia

arm_group.description: Preprocedural ultrasound-assisted midline approach of spinal anesthesia will be performed. 0.5% heavy bupivacaine will be injected to intrathecal space for spinal anesthesia.
Preprocedural ultrasound-assisted paramedian approach of spinal anesthesia will be performed. 0.5% heavy bupivacaine will be injected to intrathecal space for spinal anesthesia.

intervention.description: A preprocedural ultrasound scanning will be done, and skin marking will be made. The needle entry point and insertion angle will be determined based on ultrasound scanning. Spinal anesthesia will be performed via midline approach.

A preprocedural ultrasound scanning will be done, and skin marking will be made. The needle entry point and insertion angle will be determined based on ultrasound scanning. Spinal anesthesia will be performed via paramedian approach.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adult patients scheduled to undergoing elective orthopedic surgery under spinal anesthesia, with ASA physical status classification I, II, III
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients with contraindication to spinal anesthesia (coagulopathy, local infection, allergy to local anesthetic)
- Patients with morbid cardiac diseases
- Pregnancy
- Patients with previous history of lumbar spinal surgery
- Patients with anatomical abnormality of lumbar spine
